dipoleDirectionDescription.value: The convention used to show direction of bond dipoles

surfaceColorDescription.value: Color gradient used to represent positive and negative electrostatic potential

underDevelopment.line1.value: Real Molecules is not currently available in HTML5.

underDevelopment.line2.value: If your device runs Java, you can use the Java version at

twoAtoms.value: Experiment with electronegativity values to explore bond polarity and character.

threeAtoms.value: Explore how bond dipole size and orientation influence molecular polarity.

realMolecules.value: Explore real molecules in three dimensions.

accessibleHelpText.value: Change how strongly Atom { $atomName } attracts electrons.

dipoleDirectionChange.value: Bond dipole { $bond } arrow now points to Atom { $atom }.

accessibleHelpText.value: Explore with or without bond dipole shown.

accessibleHelpTextPlural.value: Explore with or without bond dipoles shown.

accessibleHelpText.value: Explore with or without partial charges shown.
Explore with or without bond character shown.
Explore with or without molecular dipole shown.
Show or hide labels for each atom in the molecule.
Show or hide electronegativity values for each atom in the molecule.
Explore with different charge surfaces shown.

electrostaticPotentialHelpText.value:
{ $colorMap ->
  [blueWhiteRed] Electrostatic potential ranges from positive to neutral to negative (surface colors: blue to white to red).
  *[rainbow] Electrostatic potential ranges from positive to neutral to negative (surface colors: rainbow, blue to red).
}

electronDensityHelpText.value: Electron density ranges from less to more (surface colors: white to dark grey).

accessibleHelpText.value: Turns the electric field on or off. When on, a negative plate appears on left and a positive plate on right, creating the electric field.
Turn the molecule with left and right keys, or A and D keys

rotateInSmallerStepsDescription.value: Rotate in smaller steps with Shift plus Left or Right arrow key, or Shift plus Up or Down arrow key.

adjustSliderDescription.value: Adjust slider with Left and Right arrow keys, or Up and Down arrow keys.

adjustInSmallerStepsDescription.value: Adjust in smaller steps with Shift plus Left or Right arrow key, or Shift plus Up or Down arrow key.

adjustInLargerStepsDescription.value: Adjust in larger steps with Page Up or Page Down keys.

jumpToMinimumDescription.value: Jump to minimum with Home key.

jumpToMaximumDescription.value: Jump to maximum with End key.

moveAtomAAndCDescription.value: Move atom A and C with Left and Right arrow keys, or Up and Down arrow keys.

rotateOrMoveInSmallerSteps.value: Rotate or move in smaller steps

rotateOrMoveInSmallerStepsDescription.value: Rotate or move in smaller steps with Shift plus Left or Right arrow key, or Shift plus Up or Down arrow key.

showMoleculesDescription.value: Show molecules with Space or Enter keys.

moveThroughMoleculesDescription.value: Move through molecules with Up and Down arrow keys.

closeWithoutChangingDescription.value: Close without changing with Escape key.

rotateMoleculeWASDDescription.value: Rotate molecule with Up, Left, Down, and Right arrow keys, or W, A, S, and D keys.

rotateInSmallerStepsWASDDescription.value: Rotate in smaller steps with Shift plus Up, Left, Down, or Right arrow key, or Shift plus W, A, S, or D key.

bondCharacter.value:
{ $bondCharacter ->
  [nonpolarCovalent] nonpolar covalent
  [nearlyNonpolarCovalent] nearly nonpolar covalent
  [slightlyPolarCovalent] slightly polar covalent
  [polarCovalent] polar covalent
  [slightlyIonic] slightly ionic
  *[mostlyIonic] mostly ionic
}

electronDensity.value:
{ $density ->
  [evenlyShared] evenly
  [nearlyEvenlyShared] nearly evenly
  [slightlyUnevenlyShared] slightly unevenly
  [unevenlyShared] unevenly
  [veryUnevenlyShared] very unevenly
  *[mostUnevenlyShared] most unevenly
}

electronDensityShift.value:
{ $shift ->
  [shiftedSlightly] shifted slightly
  [shifted] shifted
  [shiftedMuchMore] shifted much more
  *[shiftedAlmostCompletely] shifted almost completely
}

electrostaticPotential.value:
{ $potential ->
  [no] no
  [verySmall] very small
  [small] small
  [medium] medium
  [fairlyLarge] fairly large
  *[large] large
}

electrostaticPotentialUppercase.value:
{ $potential ->
  [no] No
  [verySmall] Very small
  [small] Small
  [medium] Medium
  [fairlyLarge] Fairly large
  *[large] Large
}

electrostaticPotentialProgress.value:
{ $progress ->
  [morePositive] more positive
  [lessPositive] less positive
  [neutral] neutral
  [lessNegative] less negative
  *[moreNegative] more negative
}

electrostaticPotentialProgressUppercase.value:
{ $progress ->
  [morePositive] More positive
  [lessPositive] Less positive
  [neutral] Neutral
  [lessNegative] Less negative
  *[moreNegative] More negative
}

electrostaticRegions.value:
{ $regions ->
  [verySlightly] Very slightly
  [slightly] Slightly
  [moderately] Moderately
  [highly] Highly
  *[veryHighly] Very highly
}

electronegativity.value:
{ $level ->
  [veryLow] very low
  [low] low
  [mediumLow] medium-low
  [mediumHigh] medium-high
  [high] high
  *[veryHigh] very high
}

molecularDipole.value:
{ $magnitude ->
  [no] no
  [verySmall] very small
  [small] small
  [medium] medium
  [fairlyLarge] fairly large
  [large] large
  [veryLarge] very large
  *[extremelyLarge] extremely large
}

orientationAtom.value:
{ $position ->
  [between1And2] between 1 and 2
  [at3] at 3
  [between4And5] between 4 and 5
  [at6] at 6
  [between7And8] between 7 and 8
  [at9] at 9
  [between10And11] between 10 and 11
  *[at12] at 12
}

polarity.value:
{ $polarity ->
  [nonpolar] nonpolar
  [veryWeaklyPolar] very weakly polar
  [weaklyPolar] weakly polar
  [polar] polar
  [stronglyPolar] strongly polar
  *[veryStronglyPolar] very strongly polar
}

partialChargeMagnitude.value:
{ $magnitude ->
  [zero] zero
  [verySmall] very small
  [small] small
  [medium] medium
  [fairlyLarge] fairly large
  [large] large
  [veryLarge] very large
  *[extremelyLarge] extremely large
}

bondDipole.value:
{ $magnitude ->
  [no] no
  [verySmall] very small
  [small] small
  [medium] medium
  [fairlyLarge] fairly large
  *[large] large
}

molecularPolarity.value:
{ $polarity ->
  [nonpolar] nonpolar
  [weaklyPolar] weakly polar
  [polar] polar
  [moderatelyPolar] moderately polar
  [stronglyPolar] strongly polar
  *[veryStronglyPolar] very strongly polar
}

shape.value:
{ $shape ->
  [linear] linear
  [nearlyLinear] nearly linear
  [slightlyBent] slightly bent
  [bent] bent
  [veryBent] very bent
  [extremelyBentSlightOverlap] extremely bent, atoms overlap
  *[atomsOverlap] linear, atoms completely overlap
}

shapeGeometry.value:
{ $geometry ->
  [linear] linear
  [bent] bent
  [trigonalPlanar] trigonal planar
  [trigonalPyramidal] trigonal pyramidal
  *[tetrahedral] tetrahedral
}

realPolarity.value:
{ $polarity ->
  [nonpolar] nonpolar
  [slightlyPolar] slightly polar
  [polar] polar
  [stronglyPolar] strongly polar
  *[veryStronglyPolar] very strongly polar
}

playArea.value: There is an interactive two-atom molecule, A–B. You can rotate the molecule, and change each atom's electronegativity to explore the effect on the bond dipole. Turn on an electric field to see how the molecule responds.

controlArea.value: Checkboxes change visibility of the bond dipole and partial charges. A radio button lets you choose to add electrostatic potential or electron density surfaces to the molecule. You can turn on the electric field, or reset the sim to start over.

currentDetails.value: Currently, the molecule is { $polarity }. The electric field is { $field }.

interactionHint.value: Change atom electronegativities to explore the effect on the bond dipole.

partialChargesDetail.value: { a11y_twoAtomsScreen_moleculeAB_partialChargesDescription } Atom A has partial { $chargeA } charge, Atom B has partial { $chargeB } charge.

electrostaticPotentialRegions.value: { a11y_twoAtomsScreen_moleculeAB_electrostaticPotentialDescription } { $regionA } { $chargeA } towards Atom A. { $regionB } { $chargeB } towards Atom B.

firstTwoRegions.value: Electron density is { $density } distributed between atoms.

lastFourRegions.value: Electron density is { $density } distributed, { $electronDensityShift } towards Atom { $atom }.

orientationDescription.value: Molecule is { $orientation } with Atom A { $atomAPosition } o'clock and Atom B { $atomBPosition } o'clock.

electronegativityValues.value: Electronegativity for Atom A is { $enA }, for Atom B is { $enB }.

playArea.value: There is an interactive three-atom molecule, A–B–C. You can change each atom's electronegativity, rotate the molecule around the central atom B, and move atoms A and C to adjust the bond angle. As you make changes, you can explore how shape and bond polarity affect the molecule's overall dipole.

controlArea.value: Checkboxes change visibility of bond dipoles, molecular dipole, and partial charges. You can turn on the electric field to see how the molecule responds, or reset the sim to start over.

currentDetails.value: Currently, the molecule is { $polarity }, the shape is { $shape }. The electric field is { $field }.

interactionHint.value: Move Atom A or C to explore how shape changes the molecular dipole.

orientationDescription.value: Molecule is { $shape } with Atom A { $atomAPosition } o'clock, Atom B at center, and Atom C { $atomCPosition } o'clock.

electronegativityValues.value: Electronegativity for Atom A is { $enA }, for Atom B is { $enB }, for Atom C is { $enC }.

molecularDipoleTwice.value: Molecular dipole is twice the size of bond dipoles.

bondDipoleABDescription.value: { a11y_threeAtomsScreen_moleculeABC_bondDipoleAB } AB bond dipole points to Atom { $atom }, { $direction } o'clock.

bondDipoleBCDescription.value: { a11y_threeAtomsScreen_moleculeABC_bondDipoleBC } BC bond dipole points to Atom { $atom }, { $direction } o'clock.

partialChargesDescription.value:
{ $sign ->
  [positive] Atom { $atom } has { $magnitude } positive partial charge.
  [negative] Atom { $atom } has { $magnitude } negative partial charge.
  *[zero] Atom { $atom } has { $magnitude } partial charge.
}

accessibleHelpText.value: Move Atom A around center Atom B.
Move Atom C around center Atom B.

playArea.value: There is an interactive molecule from a list of real molecules. You can rotate it in 3D and explore its atoms, shape, and polarity.

controlArea.value: You can use checkboxes to show or hide bond dipoles, the molecular dipole, partial charges, atom labels, and atom electronegativities. You can also choose between electrostatic potential or electron density surfaces to see how charge is distributed. Reset the sim to start over.

currentDetails.value: Currently, you are viewing { $moleculeName }. The molecule is { $realPolarity }, with { $shapeGeometry } geometry.

interactionHint.value: Choose a molecule and rotate it to explore how shape and bond polarity determine the molecular dipole.

accessibleHelpText.value: Move molecule in three dimensions. Use keyboard shortcuts to rotate molecule around vertical and horizontal axes.

objectResponses.value:
{ $direction ->
  [up] rotating up, around horizontal axis
  [down] rotating down, around horizontal axis
  [left] rotating left, around vertical axis
  *[right] rotating right, around vertical axis
}

accessibleHelpText.value: Choose a different molecule to view.

electronegativitiesTable.value: Atom electronegativities are: hydrogen 2.1, boron 2.0, carbon 2.5, nitrogen 3.0, oxygen 3.5, fluorine 4.0, and chlorine 3.0.

accessibleHelpText.value: Choose a different molecule to view

description.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] The molecule H<sub>2</sub> has linear geometry and is nonpolar, with the hydrogen atoms single-bonded. The molecule has:
  [nitrogen] The molecule N<sub>2</sub> has linear geometry and is nonpolar, with the nitrogen atoms triple-bonded. The molecule has:
  [oxygen] The molecule O<sub>2</sub> has linear geometry and is nonpolar, with the oxygen atoms double-bonded. The molecule has:
  [fluorine] The molecule F<sub>2</sub> has linear geometry and is nonpolar, with the fluorine atoms single-bonded. The molecule has:
  [hydrogenFluoride] The molecule HF has linear geometry and is strongly polar, with the hydrogen single-bonded to fluorine. The molecule has:
  [water] The molecule H<sub>2</sub>O has bent geometry and is strongly polar, with the central atom oxygen single-bonded to each hydrogen. The molecule has:
  [carbonDioxide] The molecule CO<sub>2</sub> has linear geometry and is nonpolar, with the central atom carbon double-bonded to each oxygen. The molecule has:
  [hydrogenCyanide] The molecule HCN has linear geometry and is very strongly polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to hydrogen and triple-bonded to nitrogen. The molecule has:
  [ozone] The molecule O<sub>3</sub> has bent geometry and is slightly polar, with the central atom oxygen double-bonded to one terminal oxygen and single-bonded to the other. The molecule has:
  [ammonia] The molecule NH<sub>3</sub> has trigonal pyramidal geometry and is strongly polar, with the central atom nitrogen single-bonded to each hydrogen. The molecule has:
  [borane] The molecule BH<sub>3</sub> has trigonal planar geometry and is nonpolar, with the central atom boron single-bonded to each hydrogen. The molecule has:
  [boronTrifluoride] The molecule BF<sub>3</sub> has trigonal planar geometry and is nonpolar, with the central atom boron single-bonded to each fluorine. The molecule has:
  [formaldehyde] The molecule CH<sub>2</sub>O has trigonal planar geometry and is very strongly polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to each hydrogen and double-bonded to oxygen. The molecule has:
  [methane] The molecule CH<sub>4</sub> has tetrahedral geometry and is nonpolar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to each hydrogen. The molecule has:
  [fluoromethane] The molecule CH<sub>3</sub>F has tetrahedral geometry and is strongly polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to each hydrogen and fluorine. The molecule has:
  [difluoromethane] The molecule CH<sub>2</sub>F<sub>2</sub> has tetrahedral geometry and is very strongly polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to each hydrogen and fluorine. The molecule has:
  [tetrafluoromethane] The molecule CF<sub>4</sub> has tetrahedral geometry and is nonpolar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to each fluorine. The molecule has:
  *[chloroform] The molecule CHCl<sub>3</sub> has tetrahedral geometry and is polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to hydrogen and each chlorine. The molecule has:
}

bondDipole.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] No bond dipole.
  [nitrogen] No bond dipole.
  [oxygen] No bond dipole.
  [fluorine] No bond dipole.
  [hydrogenFluoride] Large bond dipole.
  [water] Large bond dipoles.
  [carbonDioxide] Medium bond dipoles.
  [hydrogenCyanide] Small carbon hydrogen bond dipole, large carbon nitrogen bond dipole.
  [ozone] Small bond dipoles.
  [ammonia] Medium bond dipoles.
  [borane] Tiny bond dipoles.
  [boronTrifluoride] Large bond dipoles.
  [formaldehyde] Tiny carbon hydrogen bond dipoles, very large carbon oxygen bond dipole.
  [methane] Small bond dipoles.
  [fluoromethane] Small carbon hydrogen bond dipoles, large carbon fluorine bond dipole.
  [difluoromethane] Tiny carbon hydrogen bond dipoles, large carbon fluorine bond dipoles.
  [tetrafluoromethane] Large carbon fluorine bond dipoles.
  *[chloroform] Small carbon hydrogen bond dipole, medium carbon chlorine bond dipoles.
}

molecularDipole.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] No molecular dipole.
  [nitrogen] No molecular dipole.
  [oxygen] No molecular dipole.
  [fluorine] No molecular dipole.
  [hydrogenFluoride] Large molecular dipole, pointing towards fluorine.
  [water] Large molecular dipole, pointing towards oxygen.
  [carbonDioxide] No molecular dipole.
  [hydrogenCyanide] Very large molecular dipole, pointing towards nitrogen.
  [ozone] Small molecular dipole, pointing towards terminal oxygens.
  [ammonia] Large molecular dipole, pointing towards nitrogen.
  [borane] No molecular dipole.
  [boronTrifluoride] No molecular dipole.
  [formaldehyde] Very large molecular dipole, pointing towards oxygen.
  [methane] No molecular dipole.
  [fluoromethane] Large molecular dipole, pointing towards fluorine.
  [difluoromethane] Large molecular dipole, pointing towards fluorines.
  [tetrafluoromethane] No molecular dipole.
  *[chloroform] Medium molecular dipole, pointing towards chlorines.
}

partialCharges.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] No partial charges.
  [nitrogen] No partial charges.
  [oxygen] No partial charges.
  [fluorine] No partial charges.
  [hydrogenFluoride] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.38, for fluorine is -0.38.
  [water] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.31, for oxygen is -0.62.
  [carbonDioxide] Partial charge for carbon is +0.63, for oxygen is -0.32.
  [hydrogenCyanide] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.23, for carbon is +0.05, and for nitrogen is -0.28.
  [ozone] Partial charge for central oxygen is +0.15, for each terminal oxygen is -0.07.
  [ammonia] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.27, for nitrogen is -0.82.
  [borane] Partial charges for boron and hydrogen are nearly zero.
  [boronTrifluoride] Partial charge for boron is +1.02, for fluorine is -0.34
  [formaldehyde] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.11, for carbon is +0.09, for oxygen is -0.30.
  [methane] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.15, for carbon is -0.58.
  [fluoromethane] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.15, for carbon is -0.05, for fluorine is -0.41.
  [difluoromethane] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.11, for carbon is +0.10, for fluorine is -0.16.
  [tetrafluoromethane] Partial charge for carbon is +0.74, for fluorine is -0.18.
  *[chloroform] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.11, for carbon is +0.10, for chlorine is -0.16.
}

electronegativity.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] Electronegativity for hydrogen is low at 2.1.
  [nitrogen] Electronegativity for nitrogen is medium-high at 3.0.
  [oxygen] Electronegativity for oxygen is high at 3.5.
  [fluorine] Electronegativity for fluorine is very high at 4.0.
  [hydrogenFluoride] Electronegativity for hydrogen is low at 2.1, for fluorine is very high at 4.0.
  [water] Electronegativity for hydrogen is very low at 2.1, for oxygen is high at 3.5.
  [carbonDioxide] Electronegativity for carbon is medium-low at 2.5, for oxygen is high at 3.5.
  [hydrogenCyanide] Electronegativity increases from hydrogen at 2.1, to carbon at 2.5, to nitrogen at 3.0.
  [ozone] Electronegativity for oxygen is high at 3.5.
  [ammonia] Electronegativity for hydrogen is low at 2.1, for nitrogen is medium-high at 3.0.
  [borane] Electronegativity for hydrogen is low at 2.1, for boron is slightly lower at 2.0.
  [boronTrifluoride] Electronegativity for fluorine is very high at 4.0, for boron is very low at 2.0.
  [formaldehyde] Electronegativity increases from hydrogen 2.1 to carbon 2.5 to oxygen 3.5.
  [methane] Electronegativity for hydrogen is low at 2.1, for carbon is medium-low at 2.5.
  [fluoromethane] Electronegativity increases from hydrogen at 2.1, to carbon at 2.5, to fluorine at 4.0.
  [difluoromethane] Electronegativity increases from hydrogen at 2.1, to carbon at 2.5, to fluorine at 4.0.
  [tetrafluoromethane] Electronegativity for carbon is medium-high at 2.5, for fluorine is very high at 4.0.
  *[chloroform] Electronegativity increases from hydrogen at 2.1, to carbon at 2.5, to chlorine at 3.0.
}

electrostaticPotential.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] No electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [nitrogen] No electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [oxygen] No electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [fluorine] No electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [hydrogenFluoride] Large electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [water] Large electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [carbonDioxide] Medium electrostatic potential difference with even distribution.
  [hydrogenCyanide] Very large electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [ozone] Small electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [ammonia] Large electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [borane] No electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [boronTrifluoride] Large electrostatic potential difference with even distribution.
  [formaldehyde] Very large electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [methane] Medium electrostatic potential difference with even distribution.
  [fluoromethane] Large electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [difluoromethane] Very large electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
  [tetrafluoromethane] Small electrostatic potential difference with even distribution.
  *[chloroform] Medium electrostatic potential difference across molecule.
}

electronDensity.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] Electron density is evenly shared between atoms.
  [nitrogen] Electron density is evenly shared between atoms.
  [oxygen] Electron density is evenly shared between atoms.
  [fluorine] Electron density is evenly shared between atoms.
  [hydrogenFluoride] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards fluorine.
  [water] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards oxygen.
  [carbonDioxide] Electron density is unevenly shared, but symmetrically arranged.
  [hydrogenCyanide] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards nitrogen.
  [ozone] Electron density is slightly unevenly shared, shifted towards terminal oxygens.
  [ammonia] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards nitrogen.
  [borane] Electron density is evenly shared between atoms.
  [boronTrifluoride] Electron density is very unevenly shared, but symmetrically arranged.
  [formaldehyde] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards oxygen.
  [methane] Electron density is unevenly shared, but symmetrically arranged.
  [fluoromethane] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards fluorine.
  [difluoromethane] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards fluorines.
  [tetrafluoromethane] Electron density is unevenly shared, but symmetrically arranged.
  *[chloroform] Electron density is unevenly shared, shifted towards chlorines.
}
